I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed results-
based loan to the People’s Republic of China (PRC) for the Jiangxi Shangrao Early Childhood 
Education Demonstration Program. 
 
2. 
The  program  will  support  the  Early  Childhood  Education  Reform  and  Standardized 
Development  Implementation  Plan,  2020–2035  of  the  Shangrao  Municipal  Government1 from 
2020  to  2025.  It  aims  to  increase  the  total  number  of  children  receiving  quality  3-year  early 
childhood  education  (ECE)  in  Shangrao  Municipality,  which  lags  the  national  ECE  goals.  The 
proposed program is the first loan to comprehensively support a municipal ECE program and the 
third results-based lending (RBL) program in the PRC’s education sector. The program will be 
fully incorporated into the municipal government’s upcoming Fourteenth Five-Year Plan, 2021–
2025, and will provide essential support to narrow the gap in ECE outcomes between Shangrao 
and the rest of the PRC.2 
 

II. 

THE PROGRAM 

Strategic Context 

 
A. 
 
Although  the  PRC  has  achieved  remarkable  success  in  alleviating  poverty,  reducing 
3. 
inequality remains a challenge. Inequality reflects disparities in income and access to quality basic 
services  between  rural  and  urban  areas  and  between  provinces  and  regions.  Whereas  high-
quality  ECE  brings  social  and  economic  benefits,  especially  to  children  from  disadvantaged 
backgrounds,  and  reduces  intergenerational  inequality  and  poverty,3 such  gains  have  largely 
been  unrealized  because  of  limited  access  to  quality  ECE,  particularly  in  rural  areas  and  for 
disadvantaged  children.  Public  funding  for  ECE  is  generally  insufficient  and  depends  on  the 
management and financing capacity of local governments, resulting in large disparities in per child 
funding for ECE across municipalities and counties. Households bear the cost of ECE in the form 
of tuition and other fees regardless of whether ECE provision is public or private. This discourages 
low-income families from enrolling children in ECE. Recognizing the gap, the Government of the 
PRC has been scaling up its efforts to expand the provision of 3-year ECE since 2010, through 
the implementation of the first (2010–2013), second (2014–2016), and third (2017–2020) action 
plans  for  ECE  development  and  through  the  national  policy  on  ECE  reform  and  standardized 
development (2018).4 
 
Shangrao  is  one  of  the  11  municipalities  comprising  Jiangxi  Province,  located  in  the 
4. 
southeastern part of the PRC.5 With mountains and hills accounting for 75% of its total land area, 
Shangrao remains largely rural with an urbanization rate of 52%. It ranked second lowest in gross 
domestic product per capita (CNY36,836) among the 11 municipalities of Jiangxi Province in 2019.

 Per capita disposable income in rural areas has grown slowly to CNY13,346 in 2018, which is 
only about one-third of that in urban areas (CNY34,656). The population living below the minimum 
living standards (0.29 million or 4.3% of the total population) is concentrated in the rural areas. 
Ethnic minorities (12,900 people or 0.19% of the total population) live mainly in the mountainous 
rural  areas.  Since  the  1990s,  Shangrao  has  seen  large  numbers  of  out-migrants,  mainly  from 
rural areas, to the surrounding municipalities with higher gross domestic product per capita, and 
consequently, large numbers of children have been left behind by their parents. 
 
Despite  significant  progress  in  the  gross  enrollment  ratio  (GER)  in  3-year  ECE,  which 
5. 
increased  from  72.1%  in  2017  to  80.3%  in  2019,6 access  to  quality  ECE  has  been  severely 
constrained,  particularly  in  rural  areas.  The  public  provision  of  ECE  has  been  uneven  across 
Shangrao and reached only 42.4% of all children enrolled in ECE in 2019. Filling a gap in public 
ECE provision, private kindergartens have proliferated, accounting for 56.7% of all kindergartens 
(1,618 of 2,852). Yet the quality and affordability of private kindergartens vary considerably, with 
high-standard  private  kindergartens  in  urban  areas  charging  fees  more  than  four  times  higher 
than public kindergartens, and substandard private kindergartens charging marginally higher fees. 
Out of growing concern over the accessibility, affordability, and quality of ECE, local governments 
subsidize private kindergartens that meet their standards, while setting limits to the tuition fees 
they  charge.  These  kindergartens  are  classified  as  “inclusive”  private  kindergartens,  and  they 
enroll 43.5% of all children in ECE. 
 
6. 
The limited access to quality ECE in rural areas also stems from ECE teacher shortages 
and a lack of qualified ECE teachers. The ECE teacher–child ratio in rural public kindergartens 
was as high as 1:25.2, compared with the municipal average of 1:18.1 in 2019. Almost half of 
ECE  teachers  (43.7%)  work  without  teaching  licenses.  Overall,  the  ECE  teaching  force  in 
Shangrao  is  weak,  with  only  7.9%  of  ECE  teachers  holding  a  bachelor’s  degree  and  above 
(compared  with  a  national  average  of  23.9%  in  2018)  and  43.4%  having  senior  secondary 
education and below (compared with a national average of 18.1%). The main reason for the weak 
ECE teaching force is low salaries and benefits, and challenging working conditions, which makes 
the ECE teaching profession unattractive. Only 12.0% of ECE teachers, mostly working in public 
kindergartens in urban areas, have public employee status, while the rest work on a contractual 
basis  without  the  benefits  enjoyed  by  public  employee  teachers  and  the  prospects  of  career 
progression.7 ECE teacher turnover is high and many local ECE teachers choose to work outside 
Shangrao to obtain better salaries, benefits, and working conditions. 
 
7. 
The current systems for pre- and in-service ECE staff (teachers, principals, and childcare 
staff)  are  incomplete.  The  national  ECE  curriculum  guidelines  are  yet  to  be  reflected  in  the 
curriculum  of  ECE  teacher  preparation  programs.  Moreover,  existing  in-service  ECE  teacher 
professional  development  programs  do  not  meet  the  practical  needs  of  ECE  teachers 
implementing the  national  curriculum  guidelines.  Although professional  development  programs 
for principals exist, they are organized on an ad hoc basis and do not consider the fact that most 
principals were selected from primary schools without ECE experience. There are no in-service 
childcare  staff  training  programs  in  Shangrao.  Competency  standards  for  ECE  teachers, 
principals, and childcare staff do not exist to ensure the quality of training programs and guide 
continuous professional development.

 The lack of qualified ECE teachers, principals, and childcare staff is compounded by the 
8. 
absence  of  stimulating  learning  environments  rich  in  quality  ECE  support  and  resources, 
especially in rural areas. As a result, the quality of ECE staff–child interactions appear to be low, 
although  no  data  are  available  because  ECE  quality  assessment  and  monitoring  are  not 
conducted systematically  in Shangrao.  The  municipal  government’s  plan  to  expand the  use  of 
information  and  communication  technology  platforms  in  ECE  has  the  potential  to  increase  the 
quality of ECE support and resources and facilitate systematic quality assessment and monitoring. 
In addition to kindergarten-based programs, home-based ECE and community-based parenting 
programs may be necessary because many left-behind children and other disadvantaged children 
in rural areas are less likely to receive stimulation, care, and protection from stress at home and 
to enroll in kindergartens. Other countries and other parts of the PRC have adopted such models, 
targeting children from disadvantaged backgrounds, but they have not yet been implemented in 
Shangrao. 
 
9. 
In  April  2020,  the  municipal  government  approved  the  ECE  Reform  and  Standardized 
Development Implementation Plan, 2020–2035 (footnote 1), drawing on the national ECE policy 
(footnote 4) and Jiangxi Provincial Government’s ECE Reform and Standardized Development 
Implementation  Plan.  The  municipal  government’s  ECE  program  aims  to  achieve  universal 
coverage  of  3-year,  affordable,  safe,  and  quality  ECE  by  (i)  expanding  ECE  provision, 
(ii) improving  ECE  financing  mechanisms,  (iii)  strengthening  ECE  staffing  and  teaching  force, 
(iv) enhancing  ECE  management  systems,  (v)  improving  regulations  and  support  for  private 
kindergartens,  (vi)  enhancing  ECE  quality,  and  (vii)  establishing  adequate  ECE  governance 
mechanisms. 
 
B. 
 
10. 
The program builds on the experience of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and other 
development  partners  with  ECE  and  RBL  programs  in  the  education  sector  in  the  PRC.8 The 
program reflects lessons learned, including the importance of targeting disadvantaged areas and 
children,  expanding  ECE  delivery  models  beyond  a  kindergarten-based  model,  assessing  the 
quality of ECE, and strengthening program monitoring and management systems.9 The program 
is in line with the strategic priority of supporting inclusive economic growth (reducing poverty and 
inequality) set out in ADB’s country partnership strategy for the PRC, 2016–2020.10 It will support 
the following key operational principles and priorities of ADB’s Strategy 2030 in accordance with 
ADB’s  approaches  to  upper  middle-income  countries:11 (i)  addressing  remaining  poverty  and 
reducing  inequalities  and  promoting  rural  development  by  improving  access  to  quality  ECE, 
especially  in  rural  areas  and  for  disadvantaged  children;  (ii)  accelerating  progress  in  gender 
equality by promoting girls’ enrollment in 3-year ECE, labor force participation, and leadership for

assistance to receive 3-year ECE.
